title: R44088
content: The Post-9/11 Veterans Educational Assistance Act of 2008 (Post-9/11 GI Bill) provides educational assistance payments to eligible individuals from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Education's Federal Pell Grants offer grant aid payments to eligible undergraduate students based on financial need. Efficient administration is crucial for both programs to achieve their policy objectives. The administration of Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits and Pell Grant payments has been compared and criticized for delays and penalties. The House Veterans' Affairs Committee has conducted oversight hearings to ensure timely and accurate administration of the Post-9/11 GI Bill. Differences in processing are attributed to the programs' purposes. This report aims to improve the administration of Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits by adopting practices from the administration of Title IV aid, focusing on statutory and regulatory provisions and operational practices. The report reviews guidance materials, manuals, and conducts interviews to describe administrative practices for educational assistance programs. It aims to identify differences in practices and suggests ways to enhance existing practices. The report also discusses how adopting Title IV practices could improve Post-9/11 GI Bill benefit administration. It seeks to inform dialogue on streamlining and enhancing program administration. The report compares administrative practices of the Post-9/11 GI Bill and Pell Grant programs, focusing on their commonalities and key differences. Both programs are significant in terms of participants and funding, with no repayment required for recipients. The analysis aims to inform ways to streamline and enhance program administration. The report compares administrative practices of the Post-9/11 GI Bill and Pell Grant programs, highlighting key differences in their independent statutory authorizations and processes. It delves into the application process, benefit calculation, fund disbursement, and resolution of overpayments. The final section addresses issues for improvement. The federal government supports veterans through education and training programs like the Post-9/11 GI Bill and Pell Grant. These programs offer monetary assistance to eligible individuals independently. For more details on each program, refer to specific CRS reports. The federal government provides assistance to veterans and servicemembers through various GI Bill programs, including the Post-9/11 GI Bill. In FY2014, around $12 billion in GI Bill benefits were paid on behalf of approximately 1 million individuals. The Post-9/11 GI Bill aims to support qualifying individuals who served on active duty after September 10, 2001, in their transition to civilian life and retention in the uniformed services by providing educational assistance payments for approved programs. The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides educational assistance payments for approved programs of education or training, including secondary school, non-college degree programs, postsecondary degree programs, vocational flight training, apprenticeship, and licensure/certification tests. Dependents of qualifying individuals may also be eligible for benefits, including a transfer of entitlement or entitlement through the Fry Scholarship program for those who died in the line of duty after September 11, 2001. Program benefit levels were designed to cover the full cost of public undergraduate education as a reward for service during times of conflict. The Post-9/11 GI Bill covers the full cost of public undergraduate education for in-state students during times of conflict. Eligible individuals may receive various payments including tuition, fees, housing allowance, books stipend, and more. Maximum amounts are set for most payments, and individuals are entitled to 36 months of benefits. The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides 36 months of benefits that must be used within a specified period. Entitlement is charged based on pursuit of education, and individuals apply to the VA for certification of eligibility. Once certified, benefits are paid to the individual and institution. In FY2013, over $10 billion in benefits were distributed to over three-quarters of a million individuals. In FY2013, individuals received over $10 billion in Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits. Educational institutions receive reporting fees for each GI Bill participant, with the VA paying over $10 million in fees that year. The federal government supports access to postsecondary education through programs authorized by the Higher Education Act. Title IV of the Higher Education Act (HEA) authorizes federal student aid programs to help students and families finance postsecondary education. Programs include Pell Grants, Stafford Loans, FSEOG, TEACH Grants, Perkins Loans, and Work-Study programs. In FY2014, almost $134 billion in aid was provided to nearly 13 million students, with the Pell Grant program being the largest source of grant aid. Eligible individuals can receive grants while enrolled in eligible programs at higher education institutions. Pell Grants are designed to help high school graduates with financial need pursue higher education. Eligibility criteria include completion of secondary school, citizenship status, Selective Service registration, and enrollment in an eligible program at a Title IV-participating institution. Certain situations like drug convictions or defaulting on student loans may disqualify individuals from receiving Pell Grants. Eligible programs at Title IV-participating institutions include undergraduate courses, teacher certification programs, remedial coursework, correspondence programs, flight school, ESL courses, and cooperative education. Pell Grant recipients are limited to six awards or 12 full-time semesters. The maximum award amount in 2014-2015 was $5,730, subject to reduction based on financial need. The Pell Grant amount is determined based on financial need, educational expenses, and enrollment status. Students apply through FAFSA, with eligibility and expected family contribution calculated by ED systems. Over $35.7 billion was provided to 9.7 million undergraduates in FY2011. Approximately 41% of undergraduates in Title IV-participating institutions received Pell Grants in 2011-2012. On average, over 1,000 Pell Grant recipients were at each institution. About 15% of institutions had fewer than 60 recipients. The Pell Grant program provides an administrative cost allowance of $5 per recipient to participating institutions. There are differences in the administration of the Post-9/11 GI Bill and Pell Grant programs, possibly due to the age and complexity of the programs. The Post-9/11 GI Bill was enacted in 2009, while the Pell Grant program was enacted in 1973. This difference in time has allowed for more resources and experience in managing the programs. The Pell Grant program, enacted in 1973, has evolved with fully automated systems to administer aid efficiently. In contrast, the Post-9/11 GI Bill has complex benefit structures not compatible with legacy systems. The section discusses issues and concerns related to the administration of benefit payments under the Post-9/11 GI Bill, including challenges, consequences, and potential solutions. The administration of Post-9/11 GI Bill vocational flight training, apprenticeships, tutorial assistance, and certification tests differs significantly from other education programs. Certification for flight training involves completing VA-ONCE or VA FORM 22-1999 to indicate eligibility and the training plan. The form for Post-9/11 GI Bill vocational flight training requires identifying information, program name, pilot's license certification, medical certificate confirmation, credit for previous education, training hours, dates, charges, and signatures. Flight schools not IHLs must certify monthly training hours using VA-ONCE or VA FORM 22-6553c. The form also includes course details, instruction type, horsepower, charges, total costs, medical certification, completion/interruption status, remarks, and student/SCO signatures. The completed form is signed by the student and SCO and then mailed. The Certification of Apprenticeships or On-the-Job Training Certs is completed on paper or via email, using VA Form 22-1999 or training establishment letterhead. It certifies training completed in the previous month, must be submitted by the last calendar day of that month, and signed by the individual and certifying official. It includes details like program of education, training dates, hours worked, and must be accompanied by a signed training agreement. The training agreement, completed using VA Form 22-8864 or a similar method, outlines the training program, wage scale, trainee details, previous experience, planned training period, skills to be achieved, and educational curriculum. It must be signed by the VA Education Liaison Representative, trainee, and training establishment representative. The ELR facilitates program approval, ensures compliance with laws and policies, and liaises with educational institutions and training establishments. Individuals pursuing OJT or apprenticeship programs may also enroll in NCD programs. For example, those seeking permanent employment as police officers may attend a NCD program at a law enforcement academy and pursue OJT through a field training program. Certification of Tutorial Assistance (VA Form 22-1990t) is used to certify tutorial assistance received in the previous month(s). The individual must need tutoring to pass a required course and be enrolled at least half-time in a postsecondary program. The form requires identifying information, credit hour load, educational objective, course needing tutoring, and tutor's information. Certification of Correspondence Training is done by mail on VA Form 22-1999, requiring identifying information, type of training, program name, previous credits, and lesson details. The form must be signed by the SCO. Enrollment agreement for courses must be completed using VA Form 22-1999c, affirming suitability to student's abilities and interests. It includes student, course, date, institution, and credit details. The agreement must be signed and mailed to the institution for submission to the RPO. Reimbursement for licensing and certification tests requires certification by the individual. Application for reimbursement of approved tests must be completed for eligibility. National tests require a signed request with test information and results submitted to the appropriate RPO within one year of taking the test.
